dek: Egypt's contemporary artists are using the female form to express hopes and fears for the future. In this slideshow, our international editor Susan Hack showcases some recent examples.
hed: The Changing Role of Women in Egyptian Art: From Beauty to Power

items.caption: Ancient Egypt is famous for its timeless beauties, such as this dancing girl depicted in relief carving inside a mastaba tomb at Saqqara. Surrounded by a rich historic and urban heritage, and embroiled in the uncertainties of revolution, Egypt's contemporary artists are using the female form to express hopes and fears for the future.
Visitors to an art exhibition at Al Azhar Park photograph conceptual artist Mariam Fareid Adly as she walks through the space wearing bubble wrap.>>
The plastic wrap evokes modern packaging, Egyptian mummies, and the conformity of religious veiling.

Artist Alaa Awad, a professor of mural painting in Luxor, shows women saying farewell to the soul of a martyr who is welcomed into heaven by a goddess bearing a cake with candles. More than 800 people were killed across the country during the initial 18-day uprising in 2011. Awad, a Muslim, depicted the women unveiled and bare-breasted to demonstrate that Egyptian Islam is not the intolerant Wahabi Islam of Saudi Arabia. The scene is part of a mural he painted with two friends on Mohammed Mahmoud Street, in downtown Cairo, where violence between the military and protesters took place as recently as February

Part of a mural by artist Alaa Awad on Cairo's Mohammed Mahmoud Street tells the story of Egypt's revolution through pharaonic motifs. The procession of women is taken from a scene at the Ramesseum, a 3,200-year-old mortuary temple dedicated to the pharaoh Rameses II near Luxor. These women are on their way to honor former Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak, who is depicted as a mouse.

A wall builder stands by unfinished graffiti on Mohammed Mahmoud Street, near Tahrir Square. The cat and mouse clawing at the figure of a woman are authority figures from the old regime. The anonymous artist seems to have used pharaonic imagery for a sly comment on both the economic rape of Egypt by corrupt officials and the harassment of female protesters by the military, whose top generals forced Mubarak (the mouse) to leave office. The mural was painted over by pro=-army supporters a few days after this photo was taken.
In Egypt, the colloquial term for gooseberries is "sitt mistaghrabiyya," or "the covered lady." They are sold from pushcarts all over the Cairo for a few weeks in early spring.

Acrylic, silver leaf, and Swarovski crystal mixed-media work in the Cairo studio of Nadine Hammam. Hammam's theme is the condition of women in patriarchal societies such as Egypt but also as commodities in a global market place. The rabbit, she says, symbolizes corrupt Egyptian millionaires, as well as a woman's reproductive assets. Hammam was the first artist to exhibit nude works at the Art Dubai contemporary art fair, but this piece, as well as others incorporating condom wrappers, were considered too provocative to show in the conservative UAE.

Addressing the widespread concern about a persistent military dictatorship, Nadine Hammam's [Tank Girl](/daily-traveler/2012/03/Egypt-cairo-artist-revolution) an acrylic, leaf foil, and paper stencil canvas, depicts a female nude straddling a phallic pink tank with an over-sized cannon barrel that is firing rats instead of bullets. The rats, the artist says, are Egypt's billionaires, many of whom have fled the country to avoid prosecution for corruption under Mubarak's three decades in power. The silvery figure's sole piece of clothing—a red bra—is a reference to "Blue Bra Girl," the nickname for a veiled Egyptian woman who was stripped and beaten last November by soldiers in Tahrir Square. Civilian journalists caught the moment on video when the activist's abaya was ripped over her head, reviewing a sky blue brassiere, and soldiers stomped on her exposed chest.

Self-taught artist Ali Abdel Mohsen, 27, is a reporter for the Egyptian Independent newspaper and covered the International Women's Day solidarity march in Cairo last year. He witnessed men, many of whom appeared to be plainclothes security operatives, attacking female demonstrators. In the following days, the army arrested women trying to prevent the dismantling of protesters' tents in Tahrir Square and subjected detainees to forced "virginity tests." The violation of the bound female figure in this ink drawing, set against a hieroglyphic army of stick wielding figures, is psychological as well as sexual, and the graphic image of penetration references the fact that army snipers deliberately targeted many protesters in the eyes; dozens were fully blinded. The artist's post-apocalyptic ink scribbles and slashes on a "canvas" of torn cardboard boxes reflects his personal experience of "conflicts, bad news and deterioration."
items.credit: Photo courtesy Mashrabia Gallery of Contemporary Art, Cairo

items.caption: Mina Nasr Tadros, "Egyptian Elections, 2011." The life-size images, including women of different ages and religious outlooks, were originally drawn in a sketchbook as Tadros passed time standing in line to vote in last January's parliamentary election, which returned an Islamist majority. Photo courtesy Darb 17 18 Contemporary Art and Culture Center, Cairo.
items.credit: Photo courtesy Darb 17 18 Contemporary Art and Culture Center, Cairo

items.caption: Artist Nahla al Sebaei combined sonograms and images of a caterpillar, chrysalis, and butterfly in a triptych that echoes both the transformative moment and fragile power of women in Egypt's ongoing revolution.
items.credit: Photo courtesy Darb 17 18 Contemporary Art and Culture Center, Cairo
